course.subject: HUMA
course.name: Enjoyment of Western Opera
course.description: An examination of the historical development of western opera, and selected western operas with their related literary texts. This course will also put some emphasis on works that are related to Asian cultures, and operas that will be performed in Hong Kong. No previous knowledge of opera is required.

reviews.author: mxyh1904
reviews.title: Fun Class with Light Coursework
reviews.comment_content: Covers operas musically and historically throughout baroque, classical, romantic, and modern period. Operas covered this semester included the barber of seville, don giovanni, some wacky modern baroque mash-up, rigoletto, carmen, etc...
reviews.comment_teaching: The material is made really interesting. Professor Droscha performs opera himself so he does demonstrations in class and generally makes lectures really entertaining.
reviews.comment_grading: Pretty easy, just do well on the quizzes (take home and open book), attendance is counted through a code he sends in the beginning of class, the final and midterm have big weight but are easy, there is also an opera review that you have to do--probably the most time consuming assignment, but if you listen well in the lectures, its not too hard to churn out. There is also a final group project at the end, it's worth five percent but its also pretty fun.
reviews.comment_workload: Really light workload. Probably my most enjoyable class this semester because of that. You don't have to go to the lectures to understand everything on the exams, you could just read off the slides, but attending definitely helps you remember the content and reduces the study time.

reviews.author: mrtmrz
reviews.title: Excellent class for people interested in learning the basics of opera
reviews.comment_content: A general overview of the main opera epochs beginning from the baroque.
reviews.comment_teaching: Mr. Droscha is extremely passionate about what he is teaching, so it is fun to listen to him even for someone who is not interested in the opera.
reviews.comment_grading:
Exam 30% - Individual (MC questions and short questions)
Mid-term 20% - Individual (Mostly MC questions)
Opera Review 15% - Individual
Group Presentation 10% - Teacher assessment + Peer evaluation
Performance 5% - Teacher assessment
Attendance 10% - Individual
5 Online Quizzes 10% - Individual (MC and some fill in the blank)

Grading is quite easy
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is easy. There are 5 online quizzes that can be done without studying. The midterms don't require studying if one listens to the classes.

reviews.author: raeglass
reviews.title: Pretty Easy and Interesting
reviews.comment_content:
Exam 30% - Individual (MC questions and short questions)
Mid-term 20% - Individual (Mostly MC questions)
Opera Review 15% - Individual
Group Presentation 10% - Teacher assessment + Peer evaluation
Performance 5% - Teacher assessment
Attendance 10% - Individual
5 Online Quizzes 10% - Individual (MC and some fill in the blank)

For attendance, you can miss three classes no questions asked. He just puts a code up on the board at the beginning of class.

I suggest getting the opera review out of the way ASAP because you end up procrastinating on it towards the end of the semester.

He didn't have us do a performance our semester and he said that he is experimenting with different ways of doing things for the final, so keep that in mind.
reviews.comment_teaching: Every class he will lecture and show clips of the operas. You can tell he is passionate about what he is teaching and he tries to make it as interesting as possible. All of his lectures are recorded, so you can go back and watch them if you would like or miss a lecture. Sometimes he will start going on tangents about music theory elements that can be pretty confusing, but you really only have to remember the basics.
reviews.comment_grading:
All of the quizzes are multiple-choice and they are pretty straight-forward. Tends to be stuff directly from the slides.

He is lenient for the other assignments. Basically, if you do the work, he will give you a good grade.
reviews.comment_workload:
Very doable. A quiz every could operas and 2 larger assignments. You should watch the operas, as it makes the class a lot easier, but you could get by not.
You don't need to read any of the extra material if you don't want to as well. The presentation is very manageable when divided up.

reviews.author: john.c
reviews.comment_content: He covers different periods of opera: Baroque, Classical, and 20th-century, etc.
reviews.comment_teaching: Opera is not my favorite thing and I have zero knowledge of music, so I do not find the class very interesting. but i would say issac is pretty good at explaining.
reviews.comment_grading: His quizzes are not hard if you have listened during the class and studied the powerpoints.
reviews.comment_workload: Not much. 6 quiz, 1 midterm, and 1 final. I didn't watch any assigned opera and it's fine. We have to watch a live opera and write a review tho.

reviews.author: Stellar123
reviews.comment_content:
Content includes history of opera, opera types and introduction etc.

Operas covered include:
Il Barbiere di Siviglia
Don Giovanni
The Enchanted Island
La favola de L’Orfeo
Rigoletto
Wagner operas
Carmen
La Boheme
Modern operas
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor is an opera singer himself and he sometimes sings in class.  Professor has a pretty deep understanding about opera.
reviews.comment_grading:
Absolute grading.
Attendance is taken almost every lesson and  you can only skip three classes without losing marks. Many questions in quizzes and tests come from the PowerPoint.  If you study hard and listen attentively in class the quizzes won’t be difficult.
reviews.comment_workload: Moderate workload.  6 quizzes (best 5 will be counted), an opera review, a group project and a mid-year and a final exam. For the opera review, I suggest  that you watch videos of other productions online first, so that you might come up with some idea about what you’re going to write for your review of live opera performance.

reviews.author: dandelionn
reviews.title: Very interesting!
reviews.comment_content: Content covers famous operas like 'The Barber of Seville' while also diving into other aspects of opera, such as the opera house.
reviews.comment_teaching: He's very passionate about opera, and he will often sing live in the class. His powerpoints are uploaded, but it's often hard to discern what main point he is trying to make.
reviews.comment_grading: Grades are given based on five quizzes, the essay, a presentation and performance, mid-term and exam.
reviews.comment_workload: Students are required to go watch an opera in Hong Kong during the course. Afterwards, there is an essay, which is basically an opera review.

reviews.author: ust learner
reviews.comment_content: For those interested in Western opera, you cannot miss this course. You will gain deeper understanding about the opera you've watched. Besides, for those students who don't know about opera, this course gives you exposure to wide ranges of operas and you may cultivate your interests in it after this course.
reviews.comment_teaching: The slides are well prepared and the professor teaches pretty clearly. He always uses examples to explain particular concepts in Western Opera. This makes his class easy to understand and also engages students very well. So whether you're an arts student or not, I highly recommend this course.
reviews.comment_workload: Currently the workload is not a lot. But maybe we will get heavier workload as exams approach.

reviews.author: SSo
reviews.title: Great enjoyment of western opera
reviews.comment_content:
Introduce many of western operas/composers in the different musical period.  Most are Italian opera.

Many musical vocabularies you can learn, like timbre, tessitura, etc. Some terms come from Italian and German. And very difficult to pronounce. Such as Gesamtkunstwerk, which means a total work of art, this word was asked in the exam(which I can't spell it correctly lol).
reviews.comment_teaching: Issac is great!!! He is nice and super funny. He sometimes sings in class, often through improvisation, with good bass sound. Always lots of joy in this class^^.
reviews.comment_grading:
I don't have any music background and don't understand any musical notes, tabs etc. Finally got B-, happy. (btw many of my classmates have music background)

If you pay enough effort(or good at music), mostly can get higher than B grade.

Quiz (Best 5 of 6)  10%
(All MC, content come from PPT, very easy)
Final Exam 30%
Midterm Exam 20%
Attendance 10%
Opera Review 15%
(need to write 1500 words after watching an opera)

(Group presentation, introduce the selected piece of opera)

reviews.author: kkkkkkk
reviews.title: Recommended if you have music background
reviews.comment_content: This course talks about the development of Western opera and selected Western operas with their related literary texts, from Baroque to 20th-century period. You will learn a lot of musical terminology and ideology (in English, Italian, French, German) in operas, as well as some general musical term( like tempo, forte, etc.). You also learn the story and composer of each discussed opera.
reviews.comment_teaching:
He is very passionate and knowledgeable. He is always willing to answer questions too. He plays a lot of clips of opera performance in class. Majority of the lesson is watching them. You will not be bored if you are interest in music.

In the second of the term, he taught us singing for the final performance too. You will enjoy it if you like singing.
reviews.comment_grading:
Weighting
Quizzes (Best 5 out of 6)=10%
Final Exam=30%
Midterm Exam=20%
Attendance(iPRS)=10%
Opera Review(1500 words)=15%
Group Assignment(Project on assigned song)=10%
Final Performance=5%

He used absolute grading this term.
A range=90+
B range=80+
C range=70+
D=58-69
F=57 or below
And he rounded up score. My overall score was 89.6% and got A-
His grading is lenient. The mean scores of project and essay are 90%. As long as you show that you have learn something and put enough effort, he will grant you high marks. I would say if you put enough effort, you should at least get B.
reviews.comment_workload:
It is relatively heavy for a common core. The content is not difficult though. If you have musical background, you will be fine.

6 Online quiz :
Once around every 2 weeks and they are timed(25 min for 20 questions)
You need to be familiar with the content even though it is open-book. Some of the questions in these quizzes will reappear in midterm and final.

Midterm and Final:
You just have to memorize the bold text in power point for the exams. Midterm is relatively easier as 90% of the questions are MCs and the answers are obvious.  Final is a bit harder. Fill in the blanks, short question and essay are added. The most difficult part perhaps is the listening part. He will play a clips from one of the discussed opera(he will provide the playlist before exams) and ask you which opera is it from? Who write it? What is happening in this part of the story? You may find it really challenging If you have no musical background, training and bad listening.

Attendance:
He almost checked it every lesson.

Opera Review:
You also need to write a 1500-words review based on a live opera you watch.

Group assignment:
You need to work on a presentation on one of the song from the final performance. The workload is low as each group consists of 8-9 people and workload for each individual is very small.

Final Performance:
He evaluates on effort, not quality. The songs are in Italian and French. The professor know your effort by his good listening. Only 5-6 rehearsals which are not hold in regular class. You don't need to attend all to get credit.

reviews.author: Ca7
reviews.comment_content:
This course covers a lot of classic operas which are actually quite enjoyable to watch. The contents are never boring because the professor is an actual baritone who performs at opera theatres and really knows what he is talking about. I learned a lot of
opera terms and also a bit of Italian and German, which is an extra buff, seriously.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The professor uses super-detailed slides which you can always count on and consult when doing your quizzes as well as reviewing for the midterm and final. He talks like a guy in one of those dramatic movie scenes and is undeniably downright attractive! It's like you do not want to go to sleep out of an obligation to pay some respect to his charming voice, otherwise, it would be a blatant waste of good resource (I'm telling you, you do not hear this kind of very often in real life!!!)
Also, he replies emails pretty fast so if you have any questions or just cherish the opportunity to talk to a real-life star, here's your chance!
But I have to admit his explanation on how to read music is really bad, though. As a beginner, I hardly understand what he has to say when it comes to that.
reviews.comment_grading:
It's Fair. I am telling you.
One opera review
Quite a lot of quizzes though
midterm and final
And there is even one graded performance that we have to take part in
reviews.comment_workload:
Heavy as hell for someone who has no musical background (Although you will survive, obviously)
A lot of quizzes...you have to review every single time
And writing an opera review is no mean feat, trust me.

reviews.comment_content:
content mainly covered opera changes in different musical era in history.
- opera plot and composer biography
- style and music characteristics of different period
- basic music terminology
not heavy and difficult, all covered in teaching materials
will be a advantage if you have basic music knowledge
reviews.comment_teaching:
clear enough and quick response rate
videos of operas will be shown in every lecture
reviews.comment_grading:
will be fine if you have finished all assignments, projects, and get mean in mid-term and finals.
But since the class size is relatively small, so the score deviation is small, which means harder to het a higher grade.
reviews.comment_workload:
many tasks, 6 online quizzes, 1 opera review, 1 group project, 1 mid-term, 1 final exam.
but the content is rather easy so should be able to handle.

reviews.author: Jessjess
reviews.title: Great Opera Overview Course
reviews.comment_content:
The course is a great introductory exposure to the world of classical music and opera. Most of the opera chosen to be reviewed have interesting stories and music so it's not so boring. The musical terms are not hard that a non-musical background person won't be able to understand.

Isaac delves quite deep into the opera though, he'll cover the composer, story, musical theory, music style, artistic style and even the social economic background during the time of the opera.
reviews.comment_teaching: Isaac's a really knowledgeable and interesting professor. He's a professional opera singer too so he sometimes sings in class which is always entertaining. He tries to make classes fun and not boring, and you can tell he's really passionate about opera and the arts.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading is fair. As long as you show up to class and concert rehearsals, and also do all the work required.

The midterm was fairly easy but the final was hard because it quizzes on all the operas covered throughout the entire course.
reviews.comment_workload:
Attendance, Opera Review Essay, Light Reading, Watching Operas, IC Review, Midterm and Final.

-Attendance of classes and concert rehearsals are required.
-There is a final concert in the end which is fun but practice can be time consuming. Isaac isn't so particular about your singing skill, he just wants students to get a taste of performing.
-When he's discussing a specific opera, Isaac will give out readings or make us watch the opera on Youtube beforehand so that we know what he discusses in class.
-The 1000-word opera review essay isn't so bad, an opera is at least 3 hours long so there's lots of things to discuss
-The IC 500-word review are a pain in the ass, the workshops are always too avant-garde and since this is an opera class it's not that easy connecting the content with lecture materials.
-The midterm and final questions are fair. He asks about the storyline, theories, and quizzes on the opera music.

reviews.author: lemonadeb
reviews.title: Opera isn't that scary
reviews.comment_content: The course mainly covers operas from Baroque to 20th Century. Students are expected to learn the plot, voice type, compositional devices etc of each opera.  It is relatively easy to understand as a 3000+ course even if you don't have any music background because it doesn't cover much on music terminology.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof Droscha is a nice guy. He is willing to talk after-class and he treated students with pizza on the concert day.
As for teaching, he is quite humorous in a way that he always try to tell jokes and make students laugh by singing in an "operatic" way.
He tried to get the class to be more concentrate by asking you to do a few stretching with him, which is quite unique.
The only downside is that his ppt are always having too much words and it is not concise.
reviews.comment_workload:
the course do have heavy workload especially if you take it in Spring.
during the semester, you'll need to:
1. try to watch opera every time before his lessons (otherwise you'll have hard time to catch up before exams)
2. reading (well, they just provide you background of the opera)
3. Group assignment : writing programme notes for the final concert (500 words in total for 4-5 ppl)
4. hand in one opera review (and you really have to go and watch one)
5. Perform in concert at the end of semester (and attend rehearsals): it is fun if you are ok with singing ; not much pressure as the performance won't be graded
6. IC ACTIVITIES REVIEW:(
